case_title: SALEHOON vs MUHAMMAD HUSSAIN and others
complaint_summary: The petitioner alleged forgery in the Register Scheme to deprive him of land bearing Khasra Nos. 219/8, 13, and 14, which were allocated to him under the Consolidation Scheme.
investigation_summary: The court examined the Scheme Registers and recorded the statement of Shahzada Muhammad Zia, ex-Consolidation Officer, who confirmed that the entries were forged and did not bear his signatures.
judgment_summary: The court declared the forged entries void and ordered correction of the Register Scheme to restore Khasra Nos. 219/8, 13, and 14 to the petitioner. The case was referred to the Anti-Corruption Establishment for investigation.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition accepted; forged entries declared void.
legal_arguments: Bar of limitation does not apply to forged entries.
Revenue Court must protect genuine entries in the Revenue Record.

witness_statement.Shahzada Muhammad Zia: Confirmed that the entries Ex.C.I/A and Ex.C.II/A were forged and did not bear his signatures.

key_issues: Allocation of land under Consolidation Scheme

maxims.Fraud vitiates everything: The court emphasized that forged entries are void and of no legal effect.

legal_terms.Khata: A record of land ownership and allocation.

words_and_phrases.Forged entries: Entries in official records that are falsified.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around allegations of forgery in land allocation records under the Consolidation Scheme. The court found the entries to be fraudulent and void, restoring the land to the petitioner and referring the matter for anti-corruption investigation.
legal_basis: Section 13 of the Consolidation of Holdings Ordinance, 1960

orders.forged_entries: Declared void and of no legal effect

investigation.purpose: Registration of case and thorough investigation

orders.entitlement_reexamination: Petitioner's total entitlement to be re-examined
